awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CyberTraining: CIC: Framework for Integrated Research Software Training in High Energy Physics (FIRST-HEP)
awd_abstract_narration:
High-energy physics (HEP) aims to understand the fundamental building blocks of nature and their interactions by using large facilities such as the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the European Laboratory for Particle Physics (CERN) in Switzerland and the Long-Baseline Neutrino Facility (LBNF) and Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE) planned for the 2020s at Fermilab, in Illinois, as well as many smaller experiments. These experiments generate ever increasing amounts of data and rely on a sophisticated software ecosystem consisting of tens of millions of lines of code that is critical to mine this data and produce physics results. People are the key to developing, maintaining, and evolving this software ecosystem for HEP experiments over many decades. Building the necessary software requires a workforce with a mix of HEP domain knowledge and advanced software skills. The Framework for Integrated Research Software Training in High Energy Physics (FIRST-HEP) project provides a training path from a researcher's first steps through active contribution to software training and workforce development. The project serves the national interest as stated by NSF's mission to promote the progress of science by preparing a workforce trained in cyberinfrastructure and impacts STEM disciplines in terms of much needed and sought after software training.

The FIRST-HEP project directly organizes training activities and works with partners to leverage and bring synergy to disparate existing efforts in order to maximize their collective impact. It brings together an extended set of partners from the community to build not only missing basic training elements like introductory programming skills in Python, git and Unix but  also use of HEP data formats like ROOT and advanced topics including parallel programming, performance tuning, machine learning and data science for Ph.D. students. It works to build a community of instructors and experiments around the software training material and transforms the approach for research software training in HEP. It builds the workforce required for the cyberinfrastructure challenges of running and planned HEP facilities and experiments in the coming years.The FIRST-HEP education and training activities include specific goals to educate minorities in HEP, K- 12 educators and the broader STEM workforce. The K-12 teachers learn very basic skills of Unix including file management, programming languages, such as C+ and shell scripting. FIRST-HEP harnesses the potential of the underrepresented groups and works to ensure that the pool meets or exceeds the diversity in the larger HEP graduate student population when selecting both training participants and instructors for the HEP fundamental training sessions and the advanced computing schools. FIRST-HEP includes a dedicated outreach activity on cybertraining to the local Puerto Rico public. FIRST-HEP leverages engagement with the Software Carpentries to host training of  K-12 teachers at UPRM in basic Software Carpentry skills and who in turn train their students. This encourages the teachers and school authorities to consider incorporating the basic carpentries into the high school curriculum. The training and cyber skills gained during the FIRST-HEP fundamental training courses directly contribute to the broader STEM workforce and trains students to pursue data science careers and other research areas besides HEP, such as Astronomy, where similar software skills are required.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes

Award Number: 1829707 

Title:   CyberTraining: CIC: Framework for Integrated Research Software Training in High Energy Physics (FIRST-HEP)

PI: Sudhir Malik 

Institution: University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez

FIRST-HEP project laid the foundation for a transforming community framework for software training in HEP. This enables a workforce that can address computing challenges of existing, upgraded, and major new facilities like the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the European Laboratory for Particle Physics (CERN) poised for a major upgrade in 2026 and the future Long-Baseline Neutrino Facility (LBNF), and Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE). Software learning opportunities for new HEP researchers have been sporadic and vary from few university courses to host laboratory or experiment specific trainings. This implies getting trained on the job with little to no prior experience.  HEP experiments offer specific software training within the flavor of their software framework and computing environment. A significant amount of preparatory software training is common among HEP experiments, but a common training effort was lacking. This is the niche successfully filled by FIRST-HEP. It provides training path from a researcher's first steps through active contribution and worked with many partners [1-3] to leverage and bring synergy to disparate existing efforts and maximize collective impact.

Based on HEP community wide survey on software training needs, basic software modules like Shell/Unix, Git, Python and ROOT were developed followed by training sessions. Later more modules, like CI/CD, were added. The modules are open source and available via HSF Software Training Center [4]. These trainings are enabling new researchers to jump start coding and collaborate on software based projects. Feedback from over a thousand participants across the world has led to a mature basic software curriculum and periodic trainings. It has brought together an extended set of partners (including computer science) and built a community of instructors and mentors to sustain and scale the training program. The material is used by the HEP community in a continuous way and new users are now directed to the above training center. FIRST-HEP also developed advanced hands-on software training material on Parallel Programming, Data Science Tools and Technique and Machine Learning (Technology and Methods, performance evaluation) and offers them via the CoDaS-HEP Schools [5]. Its work is described here [6]. Several publications have highlighted its leadership role in software training like [7] published by the Snowmass2021 [8].

The FIRST-HEP enabled outreach activities on software training for the K-12 educators to broaden the base for future STEM workforce, especially in Puerto Rico where workshops were organized synergistically with outreach partner - Quarknet [9]. Most of these were online due to project phase significantly overlapping with COVID-19 pandemic. However, this gave a unique opportunity to reach out to teachers in Puerto Rico who had something exciting to do with their peers while working from home. Over 110 teachers were trained. The very first workshop in person introduced ideas and concepts behind programming (using python as an example) that can be incorporated in a classroom. In the later online workshops, teachers analyzed real HEP datasets from the LHC and interpreted findings by making plots. The quantitative and software experiences helped build skills that are useful in classroom and lab settings of physics and astronomy lessons. Several coding examples in Python were developed and taught using Google Colaboratory that hosts interactive Jupyter Notebooks. Based on the feedback from teachers, workshops on Arduino Programming using C++ language and Machine Learning basics were added. These activities have now scaled up to what are called as Coding Camps [10]. The work supported by FIRST-HEP has been presented at several conferences.

References:

  [1] The Carpentries: https://carpentries.org/index.html

  [2] Institute for Research and Innovation in Software for High Energy Physics (IRIS-HEP):   https://iris-hep.org/

  [3] The HEP Software Foundation: https://hepsoftwarefoundation.org/

  [4] HSF Software Training Center: https://hepsoftwarefoundation.org/training/center.html

  [5] Computational and Data Science Training for High Energy Physics: https://codas-hep.org/

  [6] Software Training in HEP, S. Malik et. al., Comput. Softw. Big Sci. 5 22 (2021)

  [7] Sudhir Malik et al, Broadening the scope of Education, Career and Open Science in HEP, Snowmass2021 (Mar 2022)

  [8] Snowmass21: https://snowmass21.org/

  [9] Quarknet: https://quarknet.org/

[10] Coding Camp: https://quarknet.org/content/coding-camp-2022
